marshall wrote:
What i am struggling with is the following:
-Called shot, yes or no? PvM build.
-Craft wand & Scribe scroll seem to be good on my current PW (WoG)
-No Blind Fight / Maximize Spell / Spell penetration feats
-I took tumble/listen as (cross class) skills cause i think they are a nice addition

So should i swap out some feats? Suggestions are more then welcome.
WoG frequenters would be better to answer the fine points but I can at least venture an opinion to consider.

Called Shot for ANY range attack - Crucial. The only other way to prevent getting mobbed is by casting high-level summon tanks and hope they last long enough (or party with a tank).

Listen at less than max I find very pedestrian and not worth the investment if you have other more pressing skill needs. Also, unless you plan to melee, maxed Discipline is about worthless except against archers shooting called shots at your arms. Opposed Leg shots should mean nothing to a zen archer. I would sooner cross-class to Set Traps/Disable Traps. A ranged attacker makes the ideal trap baiter Enemies are FORCED to close to avoid getting pummeled. Not so with a melee trapper.

Personally, I would gladly yield 2 of the Grt Wis feats in order to "buy" others (even pre-epic ones!) if they are more useful. Your DCs should be fine with WIS@32. You can buff with Owl's & Bull's to elevate the mighty damage/AB a bit more (see comment about max vs empower).

As for the Spell Pen feats, I don't think you need them. I have many caster builds in the 24 to 26 level range that take epic Spell pen and that reaches the same level at yours does without the feats and have no trouble beating most SRs. At 32 (pen = 33-52, avg 43)
it would beat most SRs. But then again, WoG may have unusually high SRs on their hostiles. Some servers do.

I prefer empower over maximize primarily due to slot management. It just seems easier to me even disregarding the higher potential of empower. I would consider it an essential buffing feat. Again, though WoG may have customized which spells can be empowered or maximized. I wouldn't know about those things.

Blind Fight has limited use with dedicated range attack since it will only provide a re-roll which IMO is not all that critical.

One other issue... Armor Skin for dedicated archer.

If pressed for feats I never use it. AC should not be much of an issue with an archer if you play it right. It should never get hit by anything but missiles, either physical ones or magical ones so even though archers are usually dexers, that exhalted DEX AC is seldom used. Even in close quarters a meatshield can be cast between you and the hostile if you plan ahead. And for that matter, Tumble has limited use. Others may play their archers differently. I built a finesser archer once and probably used the swap like 3 times the entire time. With Called Leg Shots you should be able to kite away easily enough to avoid all hand-to-hand distance where AC becomes a factor. (also comment about traps applies here)

And then you stated that it was intended as ranged support so you SHOULD take absolutely no hits and become a mage killer to allow your party to concentrate on DevCritters & high AB hitters.

Is it feasible to swap the last 2 levels to get Spellcraft to 43(45)? It would add +1 to spell saves at least. I'm not not sure if the total
feat count would change doing it that way, though.

Kail loves craft wand so I am betting it is very handy on WoG.

Just a few thoughts to enervate the grey matter a bit on a cool morning.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey mate. I have to tell you that I think your builds are quite tweakable. In fact, I would change many many things on both. so one thing at a time:

1- The fighter / CoT build:

Well, the first things that jumps to my eyes here is your stats. You don't really need 12 STR and there is ABSOLUTELY NO REASON for you to leave it. You're going to be a Zen Archer and have Divine Power, so those 4 points are better spent elsewhere. Perhaps going STR 8 and increasing your starting Wisdom. The Cleric / CoT combo can easily achieve the 38 Wisdom max possible score (18 starting, +10 stat points +10 Great Wisdom feats). I see no reason for you not to go that way. Drop either CON or DEX as low as you have to (being an archer you shouldn't need much CON anyhow) and pump your starting wisdom to 18 for better AB and spell DC.

Second of all, Cleric 32 can be ok, I guess for spell penetration, but I would rather you went Cleric 26 Fighter 4 CoT 10 for more feats, especially epic ones for max Great Wisdom acquisition. This way you can become a great caster and have an insanely high AB with a bow to deal with pretty much anything. Your implosion DC will be just spectacular the higher your WIS is. If you cap WIS, it'll be 50 WIS, which is +20 modifier. With Spell Focus, Greater Spell Focus and Epic Spell Focus on evocation, OMG. And implosion isn't affected by death immunities, so if they don't make the save, they go away. Imagine that REALLY TOUGH mage boss. You approach him invisible, fire one implosion and BOOM, he goes down. Almost feels like cheating! Spell Penetration can be a pain with the lower caster levels, and you don't really have the means to lower monster spell resistance like arcane casters (Mordenkainen's Disjunction and Spell Breach line of spells) and Druids (Nature's Balance) do. But I don't know if you know this, your DCs don't rely on caster level, they only rely on your casting ability modifier, which means, the higher your WIS is, the higher your DCs are. Spell Resistance does, however, and it works like this:

d20 + caster level + spell penetration vs. SR

Most people here im ECB know that the MAXIMUM TOOLSET SR (meaning the maximum spell resistance value that can be assigned to a monster in the NWN aurora toolset) is 32. With 26 caster levels, you would have to roll a 6 or more to penetrate the enemy spell resistance if it is at its maximum. But not all monsters have Spell Resistance, and among the ones that do, not all have the maximum possible value. 25% chance that your spells will be resisted by MAX SR monsters is pretty good. Besides, you can always buff up and revert to sniping if the spells are not working.

By dropping 6 levels of cleric, you lose 6 not much needed caster levels and 2 epic feats. Period. By adding 6 CoT levels you gain +3 to all saves and 3 Epic Bonus Feat, plus Divine Wrath, which has been changed on WoG to last longer. You are still effectively undispellable by anything but Mord's.

Now let's go to the more drastic approach. Fighter here adds a couple of good feats, WS and EWS, which is quite nice, but you don't get UMD, so I'm more inclined towards your Rogue version as a better alternative for the build. This would grant you access to Mordenkainen and Spell breach scrolls, which would ensure your spells would penetrate even max toolset SR, granted you'd be willing to follow my previous advice and switch up the spread. I'd take Fighter 1 at level 2 for earlier weapon focus, as I see no good reason not to do so. I'd take Called shot MUCH EARLIER, at lvl 3, since WF Longsword is useless except as a requirement to CoT, so why take it so early in the build if your intention is to snipe? Switch up the WF:Longsword to lvl 18 and have called shot for 15 more levels.

I'd consider dropping Craft Wand and Scribe Scroll for Spell focus and Greater Spell focus and Armor Skin for Epic Spell focus in Evocation for max implosion DC. Wands are VERY GOOD AND HANDY, but IMO for clerics, you don't really have awesome low level offensive spells that you desperately need more copies of, except for Hammer of the Gods. So I'd just rather memorize the buffs and have a +6 on Implosion DC. As Hip mentioned, you shouldn't need AC in this build, as you can slow things down and especially in WoG where you can darkfire arrows. Even more so if you are in a party, just staying back and firing punishment at mobs while your teammates are your meatshields.

I don't wanna have to try to sketch what this build would look like if you took my suggestions, I am not sure you'd have enough feats to do so, but I think so. Let me make a list of priorities so you can put your brain to work:

1- Get EWF Longbow and all the Spell Focus feats
2- Try to take Great Wisdom X for 38 ending WIS
3- Get Epic Prowess

I say this because you can end up with WIS 37, so by dropping Epic Prowess, you regain the AB through another Great Wisdom, which will also give you more spells per day and +1 to spell DCs.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
2- The Fighter Rogue build:

The first thing is that if you are going to drop anything, you should drop Fighter, not CoT. CoT gets Great Wisdom as a bonus feat, so if anything, you should go Cleric CoT Rogue, which would allow you to spread your rogue levels through the build without having to worry about XP penalty, making it more playable.

Now that I look at it, it's more or less the same advices as the previous build: get a higher wisdom, get spell focus in evocation and change the spread. Also, if going Rogue, start with rogue to get more skill points. You would lose one AB point that would be recovered with Divine Power.

Now I'm not sure you can take the War and Trickery domains in WoG, but if you can they are indeed the two best possible domains. If not, I'd give War Domain an edge, as you can get consumables with certain ease to supply your needs. I can show u a way to accumulate 100000000000 invisibility potions in WoG with a build like this, and even a few Dusts of Disappearance, which are sold at the AG.

Either build is fine, really, but I did notice you don't pay much attenction to the order in which the feats are taken, which is of paramount importance. I used to do the same thing at the beginning of my building career. That is precisely why I wrote an article on basic building stuff so that you can hopefully catch up with the rest of us in terms of knowledge. Here is the link:

http://social.bioware.com/group/2485/discussion/9490/

You may need to join the group first. Take a look at it, I assure you it'll be worth your while, and if you want to see the build I use as reference, let me know and I will e-mail it to you.

Take it EZ!

That build IMO is better than the previous one, but there are many things I would change, even though the changes are less drastic than before:

1- I would START WITH ROGUE, as I said before, because at level 1 your skill points are multiplied by 4. That way you'd get more skill points;

2- You should re-read the guide or read it all, because at some point there I do mention when you should take your rogue / monk / bard levels for skill dumps. You just randomly threw 3 Rogue levels in pre-epic with no reason, leaving the build in epics without tumble dumps(which is when it needs them the most). I would personally take Rogue 1 at 1, Rogue 2 at level 17 or 18, Rogue 3 at level 27 and Rogue 4 anywhere between 37-40. That way you ensure that your AC stays updated, ur UMD is high enough to use stuff a toon of your level will find in his /her adventures or be able to buy. So go Cleric 16 CoT 2 Rogue 2, since you're taking pre-epic feats in epics, you can take Improved Critical with that CoT 2 bonus feat and take Great Wisdom as a general feat on lvl 27 with absolutely nothing to lose.

3- Divine Power is THE BEST SPELL in the game. You should have multiple copies of it memorized, both normal and extended. Divine Power will INSTANTLY SET YOUR STRENGTH TO 18! That's why it's a total, complete and utter waste to put ANY points in Strength on a Wisdom-base zen archer. Trust me, start with 8 STR.

4- Rearrange your feats for the first few levels: Move Extend spell to lvl 3, Take Zen Archery at 6 and Called Shot at lvl 9. Zen Archery gives +2 AB (+3 at level 8), not counting any Wisdom buffs or items you may get. So Zen really needs to be prioritized over WF. Go back to the longbow, as there are better and easier to find longbows than crossbows in WoG. Ammunition for bows is also much easier to find than for crossbows, saving you a lot of money and trouble of having to restock. Take Rapid Shot at level 12 and ONLY AT 15 take your Weapon Focus. Why?? Because you are a CLERIC. Your specialty is to buff AB by a variety of means available to ya, that +1 AB won't make a difference if delayed.

5- WHERE IS EPIC WEAPON FOCUS?? Take Epic Weapon Focus at level 21, will ya?

6- Drop Craft Wand to be able to get Epic Prowess. I don't know if you know this, but you can only craft wands of low levels spells IIRC 4th or lower. Yes, you can craft a wand of Flamestrike, which is a lvl 5 spell to a cleric, but only because it's druid lvl 4.

7- Before reposting, read ALL the article I wrote, and reevaluate the build MANY TIMES. I don't mean to be rude, but the mistakes you made here are pretty basic, so take your time reevaluating the build. You still have a lot to learn so I also advise that you post your builds in the Build Request forum. Why? Because they're probably going to change drastically from the original idea, which means that they're not ready. Partly because you're not ready either. I know this first hand because when I joined the guild I was excited and I wanted to see what these guys would have to say about my builds, so I went ahead and posted 3 of them. I knew so little of the game back then, much less than you do now, and back in 2006 there were many more active members and elders to discuss the builds. I got such heavy criticism (well deserved BTW) to my builds and I had no idea why these people were "flaming" my builds so badly or even what they were talking about. They had done so well in the modules I played. Simple, I was wrong and these people knew infinitely more about this game than I did. But I had no such thing as a guide to the BASICS of character building at my disposal, so I had to learn through trial and error, which is very frustrating. And if you think that this guide is advanced, it's because you have no clue how much more complex it can get. Sorry, I know it does sound arrogant, but trust me, there is much you don't know, and that means that anything you can cough up right now will probably need serious tweaking and somewhat drastic changes to become "good". That's why the Build Request is the best place to start. I've been building for 5 years, and I still post the builds I am not quite sure about in that section. In fact, there is one there right now, a Sorcerer Bard RDD Spellsword. Just to clarify, build request sounds like a forum where you go to say: "I want a build like this this and that for a server with these characteristics, with a lvl cap of X and these restrictions" and then the people help you come up with something. Tumble works on multiples of 5 BASE RANKS, which means that no matter your DEX modifier, you will get +1 AC every 5 ranks and that's pretty much it.

However, what I understood from the text in NWN Wiki is that to cast a scroll you'd need to make a check of 1d20 + UMD which needs to surpass a DC of 25 + spell level, not the way you put it there. That would mean 25+9 = 34 is the maximum DC to cast through UMD, so you'd need 34 to ABSOLUTELY CERTAINLY cast a lvl 9 spell. So there ya go, UMD of 35 is the minimum acceptable, unless some WoG items that you may want to equip require a higher score. To emulate an alignment, the DC is 5 points higher, to emulate a race, you add +5 to DC, so on and so forth. If you want to be sure your UMD is as high as it possibly can be, then leave it at 40. Looks pretty good to me, too.

As for allocating to the Search skill, very few points are actually needed if you are a patient venturer. Let's see how well your ability to detect traps can be right now without allocating any points since Search does not require training:

Search level = 3 (Emp Fox's) + 2 (INT mod) +2 (synergy) + 10 (avg roll rounded down) = 17, which is good enough to detect just about all traps except for electrical & fire ones (and gas, naturally) IF you are a patient venturer and allow the DC checks to occur (each 6 secs.). (...and I haven't even figured Divine Trickery into the mix, mostly because it can only be used 1x/day, but it is sweet when active! +13 to those skills for at least 4 turns )

Now, if you were to shift even 4 points from Disable Traps over, retaining the synergy (5 ranks) for setting them, it would be 21, which would be enough to locate stronger versions of the above mentioned and not need to wait so long to get the good rolls. I generally find 10 points in Search is plenty especially if there are a few minor boosts from equipment.

Open Locks is another take 20 skill. So with a single point (i.e. training) and a set of +10 lockpicks, you can open DCs of 31. This is another environment-specific caveat though so Max would know better what the max enhancement for Lock Picks is on WoG and how high the lock DCs are. For a cleric (unless you need to unlock while in GSanctuary or Imp Invisibility) Flamestrike, the perfect pair of firey lockpicks, will destroy any door or container unless scripted otherwise.

I do have a question though that you may have covered somewhere in thread...

Why a single pre-epic focus feat in a melee weapon for a zen archer? The thing is: unless you anticipate well in advance that you will be needing extra AC (I am assuming that would be your basic rationale), how are you going to buff up fast enough to get any use out of it at all? If you just swap during combat you will not be hitting anything, just standing there swinging in the air. So I view that as a wasted feat in a build that is already somewhat feat-starved to begin with.

And finally, we get to Discipline.

TBH, I never even consider taking even 1 point in Discipline unless it is a strength build. I have found that unless the modified base is AT LEAST 45 in a level 40 build, you will miss most of the checks against IKD, Disarm & Called Shots. Yes, AoV & Emp Bull's will help some, but won't raise you into the mid 50's where most of the checks will be won. The whole Discipline discussion should probably be staged in a separate thread in the discussion forum. But just be aware that even fully buffed, without high strength you will subject to losing lots of Discipline checks from high AB/high damage meleers which, as a dedicated support archer, you shouldn't be facing anyway.

Don't take Point Blank Shot too literally for a Zen Archer. Although it is a prereq for Rapid Shot it really only works well for shifty high DEX archers with Dodge, Mobility, etc. While wearing heavy armor, there is little AC to be lost so UD in a build like this has limited value. A non-Monk Zen Archer just can't stand toe-to-toe while getting flanked.

But I also agree with Max about the pseudo usefulness of Concentration in an artillery build. Use those summons if you don't have a tank in your party and stay out of harms way. The real power of this build is the uncontested constant barrage of high-damage divine arrows. Once you drop that bow, it becomes a pedestrian cleric with a sword and shield.

So, that is my last two centavos *waits for the applause* on this one since even if not totally tweaked to perfection *lol*, it should perform very well. Good work!
